Archived Work

Archive

Gone, but not forgotten. Welcome to the home of retired projects. After living out long and prosperous lives as part of the main portfolio, these projects have moved on and into the archive.

Founder Stories

As part of the rollout of Kin, we developed a video series telling the stories of the challenges new and successful small Chicago businesses face. These videos tell a bit about the difficulties of scaling a business, maintaining a company culture, and the stress of hiring and onboarding new employees. Produced by Kin and directed by Frank & Harvey, these videos paint a very good picture of the problems Kin seeks to address for small businesses all over the country.

  • Art Direction
  • Content Strategy
  • Credits
Visit Site

One City Tees

One tee that combines so many of my loves: black and white, the American flag, the Chicago flag, brayer textures and my home. The One City Tee was definitely a labor of love. Initially, this was just a tee I thought up and wanted to get printed but couldn't justify the cost of screenprinting a single shirt. Luckily, it caught the attention of the Chicago Design Museum and Cotton Bureau. With wider distribution and a larger audience, I was super pumped to bring this tee to life. It was originally available at Chicago Design Museum in June 2013 and online at Cotton Bureau, but now it's only availble in my Shop.

  • Visual Design
  • Identity Design
  • Credits
Visit Shop

Very Hot Lunch

Very Hot Lunch is a design collective that meets after hours to make digital products that help people. We're pretty deep into making our first app, Let's Eat – a gluten-free dining locator. We needed to get something up fast to let people know a little bit about who we are. The splash page feeds in a big ass tweet because we live-blog every part of our process. We also post our progress at our process blog.

  • Branding & Identity
  • Visual Design
  • Responsive Design
  • Credits
Visit Site

Gogo Air

You know when you’re on a plane and are trying to connect to wifi? The wifi is Gogo Air. Sometimes you get thirty minutes for free. That’s because of a corporate sponsor.

Gogo Air was in a bad spot, creating custom one-off pages for each sponsor. These are a few example pages for the system I designed with Bright Bright Great for how advertisers would integrate their different looks into the Gogo Air log-in/authentication process while maintaining consistent usability, both for laptops and mobile devices.

  • UX & Visual Design
  • Mobile Design
  • Credits

AARP Foundation's Youth Campaign

The 18-24 year old demographic is known for their desire to make a difference in the world, but there's little education or awareness for them around the issues fifty and older Americans face on a daily basis. Unconditional is AARP and AARP Foundation's campaign to raise awareness with the younger generation and encourage advocacy for one of the most vulnerable groups in America, those aged fifty to sixty-five.

I concepted and created the art direction and pitch creative. The look is raw and serious while at the same time human and empathetic.

  • Branding & Identity
  • Visual Design
  • Credits

Chicago Community Trust's Leadership Campaign Microsite

The Trust is looking to dramatically increase their capitalization. Normally, they focus on the good work they do in Chicago through their grants. However, in order to really speak to a high-end donor in a sophisticated and targeted way, they worked with Lipman Hearne to launch a leadership campaign called We Are Chicago. The campaign appeals to very wealthy prospective donors by highlighting major donors who are leaving a legacy in the city right now and by emphasizing the Trust's efficiency and history of community impact.

  • Visual Design
  • Responsive Design
  • Credits

Live The Square

As part of OWL Design Collective, I made some icons for one of our self-intiated projects, LiveTheSquare.com. Live The Square curates and aggregates info about the best of what’s going on in Logan Square, a Chicago neighborhood. These mono-weight icons supplement some FF Neto icons already in use.

  • Illustration
  • Visual Design

University of Wisconsin's Annual Fund Campaign: Share The Wonderful

UW-Madison and the UW Foundation needed to raise $10 million dollars in 2012 to help the University continue its excellent teaching and research in spite of diminishing state funds. For the first time in their history, they enlisted the help of an agency to lead the marketing efforts of their Annual Fund Campaign. Lipman Hearne was one of eight agencies competing for the work.

Leading up to the pitch, I designed all the digital spec work, and after winning I continued to art direct the project to completion. Share The Wonderful is the name of the campaign, and our goal and my personal ambition with the project was to make each facet of the campaign feel like a gift to the person on the other side of the screen. The campaign began in mid-September 2012, and by mid-December it had exceeded its 10 million dollar goal.

  • Branding
  • Art Direction
  • Visual Design
  • User Experience & Interaction Design
  • Responsive Design
  • Credits
Visit Site

Heartland Community Church

As the church grew from one location to three, the Heartland website needed a redesign to improve usability for satellite-location attendees. The old site focused on the main campus and had numerous no-traffic pages. The redesigned site greatly improved the user's experience by streamlining key information.

  • User Experience Design
  • Creative Direction
  • Content Strategy
  • Credits

University of Texas Arlington's Yes Campaign

Big things are happening at the University of Texas-Arlington. Over the last decade, the university has evolved from a commuter campus to a nationally recognized research institution. The Yes Campaign highlights the great work the university is doing in order to lay the ground work for a capital campaign in 2013.

  • Visual Design
  • Interaction Design
  • Responsive Design
  • Credits
Visit Site

University of Louisiana Lafayette

UL Lafayeete needed a new site to replace a very old, very bad site. The new site improves usability, content and design as well as supports admissions growth.

The Me I Want To Be

Christian author John Ortberg’s book The Me I Want To Be was released with multiple cover options. As a way to emphasize the themes of the book, readers select the book cover they prefer most. Zondervan ran these full-page ads in Christian magazines to promote the book. The imagery is taken from short films we created to support the book's content.

  • Branding
  • Art Direction
  • Illustration
  • Credits

The Office of Jason James

After seven distinct art directions and six months, I finally landed on a look for my stuff that felt both personal and representative of my work. Blending both the mess of analog with the precision of digital, I finally felt resolved (for about a year and a half). With stamps, letterhead, thank you's, business cards and more, the Office of Jason James is open for business. Drop me a line so I have an excuse to mail you something.

  • Branding & Identity
  • Visual Design
  • Credits

Zombie Research Society

As part of 2 Night Stand Chicago 2011, I designed a new site for the Zombie Research Society and met a bunch of new Chicago designy friends. ZRS focuses on the pseudo-science of zombie medical research. They take the “imminent” zombie apocalypse very, very serious. Therefore, the design walks a thin line, balancing clinical and horror film aesthetics.

  • Visual Design
  • User Experience Design
  • Front-end Development
  • Credits

Seriously Thanks

Sometimes you get a really great gift, one you still use years later. Seriously, Thanks was created to celebrate those gifts and publicly thank the gift givers. As part of the OWL Collective, I drew all the handdrawn typography and illustrations.
